description.narrative: I. Number of men with access to legal aid services II. Number of women with access to legal aid services III. Number of magistrates stagiaires definitively appointed IV. Existence of library at CENFOJ V. Existence of a mechanism of pending cases update VI. Existence of thematic report on compliance of judicial decisions with domestic legislation and international

comment.narrative:
I. 3106 men (figures updated on 31st December 2013) have been assisted with free legal aid in the Capital of Bissau and 3 Regions (Oio, Cacheu and Bafata)
II. 852 women (figures updated on 31st December 2013) have been assisted with free legal aid in the Capital of Bissau and 3 Regions (Oio, Cacheu and Bafata)
III. 13 magistrates stagiaires are not definitively appointed
IV. No library at CENFOJ
V. Lack of updated data on pending cases in the Courts
VI. Lack of mechanism to assess the compliance of judicial decisions with human rights standards

I. 6800 people benefited from free legal aid services in Bissau and regions II. 37 magistrates stagiaires are definitively appointed in Courts of Bissau and Regions III. A data system is established and functioning IV. 2 Sector level courts in Cacheu and Mansoa Regions constructed and operational

I. Achieved: 8466 people benefited from free legal aid services in Bissau and regions II. Partially Achieved: 14 intern magistrates were definitively appointed in Courts of Bissau and Regions III. Not Achieved: A data system is established and functioning (this expected result has not been achieved) IV. Achieved: The Two courts were constructed, equipped and handed over to the Government. One is already operational

I. 8.813 people benefited from free legal aid services in Bissau and regions. II. 30 people attended the in-take career course of clerks at CENFOJ III. 16 magistrates trained IV. A database system is established and functioning V. A study on efficiency and effectiveness of justice service delivery is available VI. One performance evaluation of magistrates VII. One training on fight against corruption

1. Existence of a legal framework, including regulations and Decree, for the creation of 2 terrestrial parks and 3 corridors in the complex Dulombi-Boe-Tchetche (DBT); 2. Increased scores on the GEF4’s PA Management Effectiveness Tracking Tool “METT” for all five target sites within the DBT Complex 3. Increased scores on the UNDP’s Capacity Development Scorecard for Protected Areas Management over the baseline 4. Results from the application of UNDP’s Financial Sustainability Scorecard

comment.narrative: 1.No legal framework exist to allow Institute of Biodiversity and Protected Areas (IBAP) expand the protected areas in Dulombi-Boe-Tchetche (DBT) Complex 2.METT scores for (a) Dulombi NP:19; (b) Boé NP: 20; (c) Cuntabane-Quebo Corridor:19; (d) Salifo Corridor:19; (e)Tchetche Corridor: 21 3.Systemic: 14 / 30 (44%); Institutional: 24 / 45 (54%); Individual: 10 / 21(46%); (General avg. 49%) 4. Total Score for PA System = 40 out of a total possible score of 197 (i.e. 20%)

1. A dossier for the offcial creation of the 5 terrestrial protected areas constituted and submitted to the Council of the Ministers for aproval and consequent issuance of the Decree of Creation before end of December, 2016, establishing legally the 5 terrestrial protected areas already established and operating " de facto" in Dulombi-Boe-Tchetche Complex
2.Management effectiveness tracking tool (METT) scores for (a) Dulombi NP:22; (b) Boé NP: 23; (c) Cuntabane-Quebo Corridor:22; (d) Salifo Corridor:22; (e)Tchetche Corridor:24
3.The Capacity Development Scorecard (CDS) values are: Systemic:17 /30 (56,7%); Institutional:27/45 (60%); Individual:13/ 21(62%); (General avg. 59,6%)
4. The financial sustainability scorecard (FSC) measures the financial sustainability of the management of the PA. The results of the 2015 mid-term evaluation are: total score of 80 out 220, or 36%.

1. Dossier constituted and submitted but not approved yet. No Terrestrial Protected Areas legally established, despite their existence "de facto".The required preliminary studies (socio economics and environmental impact assessments) required for the PAs legal creation and classification were completed, and the package of laws and regulations fully prepared for the creation de jure of the 5 PAs (2 parks and 3 corridors); the environmental compliance declaration been issued by the Environmental Impact Assessment Authority; this target is on track, as it is expected that before the end of year, the Council of the Ministers will approve the official creation of the aforementioned 5 PAs.
2.The results demonstrate a significant improvement in the METT on DBT Complex management: Dulombi National Park: 71; Boe National Park: 74; Salifo Corrdior:74; Cuntabane-Quebo Corridor: 69;Tche-tche Corridor: 70. The knowledge about the species has increased considerably with the work of IBAP and partners including the Chimbo Foundation, through the production of regular publications (newsletters/ research findings) Hunting pressure decreased considerably with the presence and action of the guards-parks. The observation of different species of animals have been more frequent, including in new areas where they never have been shown. For instance, during this reporting period, no direct observations and/or traces of Elephants have been reported but, on the other hand, the observation of carnivorous species has increased from 9 to 15. A photo taken on lions confirmed this affirmation. Regarding the primates, some species supposed extinct or non-existent, were observed rising the number of primates from 5 to 9. In total the number of mammals has increased from 33 to 44 species. Dulombi Park as registered greater diversity of ungulates. The new studies commissioned by IBAP concluded that chimpanzee populations has increased, with more than 1,000 individuals which reveal the importanc

description.narrative: To establish and operationalize terrestrial PAs in the DulombiBoéTchetche DBT complex and thereby significantly expand and strengthen GuineaBissaus PA system
3 The status of emblematic species such as the African elephant in the Dulombi NP and the western Chimpanzees in the Boé area

comment.narrative:
According to recent survey by Chimbo Foundation there are approximately 500 chimp individuals in the Boé area
Elephant survey will require update
Populations of emblematic species maintained stable

Following the MTR recommendation one indicator has been adopted Chimpanzees It is estimated that the current population is stable and is about 800 individuals according to Chimbo Foundation estimates There is a considerable increase of other primate species and ungulates due to considerable decrease of hunting activities in the complex as a result of the supervision by DBT ParkGuards awareness and fear of contamination of zoonosis and in particular of the Ebola virus
Effective compliance with the protection of wildlife is having positive effects on the growth of different species It is observed that the elephant population is very small and given their crossborder migration it is difficult to carry out effective followup Observations of other emblematic species are very frequent like the Hippo in the Corubal River and Red Antelope Hippotragus equinus in all DBT Complex sites Furthermore signs of the presence of Lions Panthera were also observed in Boé

description.narrative: Immediate threats to terrestrial ecosystems mitigated through the effective expansion and management of PAs in the forest belt region
4 Increased scores on the GEF4s PA Management Effectiveness Tracking Tool METT for all five target sites within the DBT Complex

comment.narrative:
1 Dulombi NP 19
2 Boé NP 20
3 CuntabaneQuebo Corr 19
4 Salifo Corridor 19
5 Tchetche Corridor 21

All scores are gt 30 by the MTE
All scores are gt40 by end of project

According to the METT criterion as defined in the project document the score below shows that there is improvement in the management of the DBT Complex
The METT values continue improving within the DBT Complex and the biggest threats are being efficiently managed by the project sites management structure actively presents in the project sites with high support of the key local actors farmers hunters traditional chiefs CBOs leaders and local administrative officials The increase in the awareness of these project partnersbeneficiaries has contributed for the conservation of PA forest ecosystems its fauna and flora by mobilizing communities against illegal logging and encouraging its members to abandonreduce slash and burn practices for agriculture purpose use of fire in traditional beekeeping and harmful illegal hunting poisoning animals burn forest to stimulate grass regeneration Furthermore this has contributed for controlling new settlements within the PAs for a minimal level in the buffer zones of the parks from migration of people from across the border Although the Angolan bauxite mining concession is outside the proposed PAs there is still a concern about the impacts of transporting the ore via rail or road through the CuntabaneQuebo Wildlife Corridor to the Buba sea port for export and the impacts of future mining activities on the watershed of the Corubal River Basin critical to the region The modification of the natural ecosystem by fires of different origins persists but in minor scale The causes of the fires are being actively discussed and the measures widely disseminated through socioprofessional associationsCBOs of farmers and hunters youths and women covering all the extent of the DBT Complex Evasive species pollution and major geological events except for the siltation of some rivers streams and springs are unknown Best traditional conservation management practices are being revitalized with the support of village community volunteers leaders and authorities
Dulombi 65
Boé 62
Tchetche 61
CuntabaneQuebo 61
SalifoXitole 60
Average 616

description.narrative: Improved systemic and institutional capacity provides the enabling framework for establishing and managing a more representative PA network
5 Increased scores on the UNDPs Capacity Development Scorecard for Protected Areas Management over the baseline

comment.narrative:
Systemic 14 30 44
Institutional 24 45 54
Individual 10 21 46
General avg 49
Scores expressed in absolute terms increase by at least 20

The Capacity Development Scorecard CDS tool measure the improvement of the capacities of the actors involved in the management of the PA It has been applied in the formulation of the project in 2009 It takes into account the systemic level DBT complex as a whole the institutional level entities involved and the individual level During the project MidTerm Evaluation exercise the CDS has been applied to measure the evolution in the development of capacitybuilding since the launch of the project The results of the midterm evaluation are systemic 2030 64 Institutional 2945 63 Individual 1021 52 Average general 61 While training needs assessment has not been performed at the start of the project the current technical human and logistic capacities of IBAP have been strengthened IBAPs cadres have benefitted from relevant training provided on PA management SIG strategic planning micro projects formulation PA creation process that contributed to increase their awareness and capacity to fulfil their duties According to the MTR report efforts have to be dedicated in upgrading the staff technical capacity for which a capacity development plan must be prepared and implemented In addition to that development of sustainable mechanism of financing the National Protected Area System management cost must be ensured

description.narrative: 6 Results from the application of UNDPs Financial Sustainability Scorecard

comment.narrative: Total Score for PA System 40 out of a total possible score of 197 ie 20
Scores expressed in absolute terms increase by at least 30

The financial sustainability scorecard FSC measures the financial sustainability of the management of the PA It was applied in 2009 to the National system of protected SNAP areas during the project document formulation at the same time as the METT It was revised in June 2012 and then in 2014 The midterm evaluation team has analyzed all of the FSC made by the various IBAP projects The scores obtained differs much from one to the other FSC The team concluded that IBAPs need to harmonize its monitoring system at a centralized level eg at level of IBAP financial unit in order to have a more credible consolidated tool
The results of the midterm evaluation are total score of 74 out 220 or 34

description.narrative: Participatory conservation management approaches in the DBT Complex are implemented

comment.narrative:
Not Applicable
The MSC technique is to be applied once the project has been launched and some form of change has occurred The baseline corresponds to all assessments that corroborate the situation analysis for this project particularly with respect to landuses and livelihoods
Changes in livelihoods are perceived through the independent application of the MSC technique

Through the MSC it was verified improvement in the perception that the parks are with and for the populations to decide on the rights of use and access in the areas of sustainable development within the Park its important to reinforce their traditional social mechanisms of control and management of space and natural resources as well as taking into account their heritage knowledge norms and cultural practices regarding management of the PA of the DBT complex the information awareness and training of policy makers provided have led to a positive change in perception of the role and function of the protected areas in biodiversity conservation for economic and sociocultural activities support climate change mitigation food security and poverty reduction

description.narrative: The ultimate development objective to accomplish is to ensure that high level policies and management plans relating to agriculture and water sectors explicitly consider climate change risks and opportunities.
independent political entity
To increase resilience and enhance key adaptive capacity to address the additional risks posed by climate change to water and agriculture sectors in Guinea Bissau
1 High level policies and management plans relating to agriculture and water sectors explicitly consider climate change risks and opportunities

comment.narrative:
The following policies plans are not climateproof
National Plan of Agricultural Investment PNIA
National Program on Food Security
Water Directive Water Code
Poverty Reduction Strategy II

At least two high level policies National Plan for Agricultural Investimment Region Gabu Local Plan Development Water and Sanitation Policies National Plan Livestock development management plans explicitly consider climate change risks and opportunities

Significant progress has been made towards the achievement of this DO target i 40 keys cadres from 16 keys line ministers have acquired knowledge on climate change mainstreaming methodology and have actively participated in the application of the methodology integrating CC issues into the target policy documents and plans Agricultural Development Policy Letter Water and Sanitation Master Plan Livestock Development Policy Letter National Strategy for Poverty Reduction and Gabu Region Local Development Plans Piche and Pirada administrative sectors These documents have been revised integrating climate changes issues following the validation workshops held in Bissau and Gabu Is expected that by the end of the year this policy documents and plans will be adopted by the Government

description.narrative: 2Government and international funding allocated to managing climate change risks increased

comment.narrative: lt25000 USDyear
At least 100000 USDyear

The project team National Project Coordinator Agricultural Specialist and Climate Change Adaptation Specialist has provided assistance to the Government in its partnership with a West African Development Bank BOAD for a project proposal formulation on climate change adaptation in amount of 10000000 USD to the Board of Adaptation Fund before end of the year b European Union under Global Climate Changes AllianceGCCA funding for formulation of project proposal on adaptation and mitigation to climate in order to strengthen the resilience of communities of the Bafatá Gabu Quinara and Tombali regions This project is in its final stage and the planned funding are of 4 million euros and is virtually guaranteed This project will strengthen the adaptation initiatives envisaged under the current NAPAResilience project in the Gabu region
UNDP CO and Regional Technical Advisor have provided technical support to the Government in the elaboration of a 125 million USD project proposal on climate change adaptation in coastal area and a 5 million USD project proposal on early warning system development The adaptation project was approved but as LDCF is exhaust therefore these two projects are under reformulation seeking GCF funding
Within the framework of partnership with the Directorate General of Livestock the Government through Monetary Union of West Africa UEMOA has provided 25000 USD for the vaccination of cattle against carbuncle hematic and symptomatic Also under the same framework 25000 USD were invested in the construction of 4 veterinary clinics 1 small slaughterhouse and 1 butcher shop in some of the project targeted villages in Gabu Region
These two initiatives will support the achievement of the target under this DO

description.narrative: 3 Scores of UNDPs Vulnerability Reduction Assessment VRA to be applied upon inception midterm and endofproject in projectsite communities

comment.narrative: As of results after the application of the tool at project inception
Aggregate reduction of 1035

The exposure to the risks are the same but the vulnerability of the communities has decreased thanks to increase of awareness on climate change issues and the adoption of sustainable solutionstechnologies such as cereal banks fodder plants cultivation resilient agricultural techniques improved wells for water adductionpumping etc during the reporting period the following has contributed for strengthening the communities resilience to climate change i draft report identifying keys national actors suitable to address climate risks management and proposing a Commitment Plan for climate risks management to be signed by all of them is available ii 10 Contingencies Plans for 10 villages are developed and adopted iii four 4 national technicians have acquired knowledge on climate change risks and vulnerability analysis and mainstreaming methodology through a training course provided by a Burkina Faso Specialized Training Institute v the Rural Forum on Climate Change and the Environmental Surveillance Committee has met quarterly and promoted awareness campaigns on Ebola Virus Disease deforestation implications in climate change need to preserve their natural heritage through a participatory and holistic approach

description.narrative: Elections - elections

1) Elections Générales sont organisées de façon efficace et dans les délais accordées par les acteurs politiques nationaux, dans le cadre du calendrier de la transition politique ; (2) Les élections sont considérées libres, transparente et justes par les MOE et acteurs politiques nationaux.

comment.narrative: Après le coup militaire du 12 avril 2012 qui a interrompu les élections présidentielles du 12 mars 2012 empêchant l’élection du président de la république de façon démocratique, le pays a entamé à nouveau une période de transition politique. Cette période doit s’achevée avec des élections libres et justes avant la fin de 2013. Par accord politique et tenant compte de la fin du mandat de la CNE, un nouvel secrétariat exécutif de la CNE vient d’être élu et n’a pas beaucoup d’expérience dans le domaine électoral. Des formations de mise à niveau en administration électoral ont été conçues et délivrées aux membres du secrétariat. Le calendrier électoral est très serré et il y un risque de dérapage du calendrier. La mobilisation des ressources est toujours reste en-deça des besoins et un effort additionnel de la part des partenaires s’impose.

1. 36 hommes et 22 femmes 2.. Le mécanisme de coordination pour élaboration de politique nationale est établi 3. 6 règlementations et 8 guides sectoriels sont disponibles. 4. Un programme radiophonique est établi et diffusé 5. Vingtaine d'ONG et d'OCB qui forment la plateforme sont identifiées.

1. 6 hommes et 1 femme 2. Le mécanisme de coordination pour élaboration de politique nationale est établi. 3. 6 règlementations et 8 guides en cours d'élaboration. 4. Un programme radiophonique n'est pas encore établi. 5. Quarantaine d'ONG et d'OCB qui forment la plateforme sont identifiées.

1. 100 hommes et 100 femmes 2. --- 3. 6 règlementations, 1 plan intégré de travail et de formation pour la DGFF, 2 mémoranda d'accord pour le partenariat entre la DGFF et institutions homologues étrangères, 8 guides sectoriels d'évaluation d'impact environnemental, 1 guide d'évaluation stratégique de l'environnement, 1 guide d'évaluation économique de l'environnement, 1 politique nationale de l'environnement et du développement durable 4. Les informations sur l'élaboration de politique sont diffusées. 5. Un cadre de plateforme est établi.

comment.narrative: La Guinée –Bissau est confrontée au désintérêt croissant des populations pour la gestion publique, et à la faible participation effective du plus grand nombre aux prises de décisions stratégiques pour le pays, ce qui constitue de fait une entrave majeure à la gouvernance démocratique.

1. Révision de la législation et le fonctionnement de l'ANP (Règlement intérieur, les statuts de carrière des fonctionnaires parlementaires et des règles interne du Conseil d'administration du Parlement) 2. Les rapports sur les actes de corruption dans l'exercice des activités public disponible 3. Capacité du personnel du Parlement est renforcée pour améliorer le fonctionnement du Parlement 4. Renforcement des capacités de l'ANP dans les domaines du contrôle et de la supervision des actions du gouvernement qui tiennent compte de la perspective de genre 5. Les organismes de gestion des élections ont des capacités pour assurer des processus efficaces, transparents, participatifs et électoraux crédibles qui sont sensibles au genre 6. Les institutions publiques et les organisations de la société civile ont la capacité de budgétiser, de définir un cadre de gestion et mettre en œuvre des politiques sensibles au genre qui répondent aux priorités du public.

1. Les capacités de l’ANP sont renforcées dans les domaines de la représentation, de la législation, du contrôle et de la supervision des actions du Gouvernement qui prennent en compte une perspective de genre. 2. Les organes de gestion des élections ont la capacité d’assurer des processus électoraux efficaces, transparents, crédibles et représentatifs ouverts à la participation des femmes. 3. Les institutions publiques et les organisations de la société civile ont la capacité de budgétiser, de définir une structure de gestion sensible au genre et de mettre en œuvre des politiques qui répondent aux priorités du public
